title: Easy Ways to Send Photos from Computer to Phone: Android & iPhone

steps.title: Open the Google Photos website on a computer.
steps.content: Open the Google Photos website on a computer. Go to https://photos.google.com/ . This will open a page with your phone's photos if they are backed up. You may first have to sign into your Google account with your email address and password if this is your first time opening Google Photos. You can use Google Photos on Android or iPhone, Windows or Mac. While it's easier for Android phones to use Google Photos, iCloud is seamless for iPhone users.

steps.title: Click +.
steps.content: Click + . This plus button is in the top right corner of the browser page and will open another menu. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click Import photos.
steps.content: Click Import photos . It's the first option under the "Add photos" header. Clicking this will cause Finder (Mac) or File Explorer (Windows) to open.

steps.title: Select photos to upload.
steps.content: Select photos to upload. Click and drag your mouse across a group of pictures you want to select or hold down Ctrl (Windows) or ⌘ Command (Mac) and click each picture you want to select individually.

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. Once your photo uploads in Google Photos on your computer, you can then open the Google Photos app on your phone to see it. You will need to log in if you aren't, and you need to make sure that your computer and mobile are synced. To do that, there are a few places for you to check: iPhone & iPad: Tap your profile picture or initials in the top right corner of the app and check the backup status. If it's off, you need to turn it on in Settings > Backup > On . Android: Open the Google Photos app and tap your profile picture or initials in the top right corner. Look for your backup status, which is usually indicated by a ring around your profile picture. If Backup is off, you need to turn it on by going to Settings > Backup > On . [2] X Research source Keep in mind that backing up and syncing your photos may take a while, depending on the number of photos transferred, your internet connection, and other conditions including internet speed.

steps.title: Open the iCloud site and log in if needed.
steps.content: Open the iCloud site and log in if needed. Go to https://www.icloud.com/ on your computer and click Sign In . Enter your Apple ID and password that you use for your iPhone, then click → . This will log you into your iCloud account.

steps.title: Click Photos.
steps.content: Click Photos . The icon for "Photos" is a multicolored pinwheel icon on a white background. Doing so will open your iCloud Photos app. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click the "Upload" icon.
steps.content: Click the "Upload" icon. This icon resembles a cloud with an upward-facing arrow. Clicking it prompts a File Explorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac) window to open. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Select photos to upload.
steps.content: Select photos to upload. Click and drag your mouse across a group of pictures you want to select or hold down Ctrl (Windows) or ⌘ Command (Mac) and click each picture you want to select individually. [5] X Research source Click Open in the bottom right corner of the window to begin uploading your selection or double-click them.

steps.title: Open Photos on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open Photos on your iPhone. You must have iCloud Photo Library enabled on your iPhone to see the pics that you uploaded. To enable iCloud library, go to Settings > Your Name > iCloud > Photos and tap "Sync this iPhone . The photos uploaded from your computer will take some time to show up on your phone depending on how many photos you're uploading and your internet connection.

steps.title: Turn on AirDrop on both devices.
steps.content: Turn on AirDrop on both devices. You can find the icon for AirDrop in the Control Center (iPhone) and in the Control Center menu on your menu bar (Mac). To open your iPhone's control center, swipe down from the top right side of the screen. If you have an older iPhone with a Home button, swipe up from the bottom instead. On your Mac, click the icon on the top right side of your screen that looks like a pair of toggle switches. Tap or click the icon that looks like a series of concentric circles with a wedge cut out of the bottom to enable AirPlay. If AirPlay is on, this icon will be blue. Also make sure Wi-Fi and Bluetooth are enabled on both your Mac and iPhone. The iPhone and Mac have to be within 30 feet or 10 meters of each other. When you turn on AirDrop, select Contacts Only or Everyone so you can transfer images between the devices. You can do this by long-pressing the icon on your iPhone or clicking the arrow icon next to the AirDrop control on your Mac.

steps.title: Navigate to the photo you want to share in Photos.
steps.content: Navigate to the photo you want to share in Photos. Alternatively, open Finder and click AirDrop from the sidebar.

steps.title: Click and click AirDrop.
steps.content: Click and click AirDrop . You'll see this rectangle with an arrow pointing upwards in the toolbar. If you're using the Finder alternative, drag items that you want to AirDrop into this folder.

steps.title: Select the person you want to share with.
steps.content: Select the person you want to share with. If your phone doesn't appear, you may need to start AirDrop again, especially if it's been more than 10 minutes. On your phone, click Accept to receive the AirDropped pic. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on Quick Share on your Android.
steps.content: Turn on Quick Share on your Android. Quick Share has replaced Nearby Share as the default sharing software and Nearby Share is no longer included on some Android phones, like the new Galaxy phones and tablets. [7] X Research source You can long-press the Quick Share icon in the Quick Settings panel, or find it in Settings > Connected devices > Quick Share . Make sure "Who can share with you" is set to Contacts only or Everyone for your PC to be able to send pictures to your Android.

steps.title: Open Quick Share on your computer.
steps.content: Open Quick Share on your computer. You need a 64-bit version of Windows 10 and up to use this software. Go to this link to download the Android software . This is not the same as downloading the Samsung version of Quick Share, which is available through the Microsoft Store; that version will only work with Quick Share on Samsung phones and tablets. Make sure Bluetooth is on for both your Android and computer. Turn on Wi-Fi on your Android and computer . Connect both devices to the same network. Make sure both devices are within 16 feet or 5 meters of each other.

steps.title: Click Select or drop files to share to your phone.
steps.content: Click Select or drop files to share to your phone. Find the folder or the file of images that you want to share, then share them using "Select" or by dropping them in the Quick Share dotted section.

steps.title: Click your Android in the "Nearby Devices" section.
steps.content: Click your Android in the "Nearby Devices" section. You should see the name of your Android here. If not, make sure Quick Share is enabled on your phone or tablet (it's in the Quick Settings panel). You might need to redo the sharing process (Selecting "Who can share with you") if it's been more than 10 minutes.

steps.title: Tap Accept on your phone.
steps.content: Tap Accept on your phone. If your phone is unlocked, you'll see a Quick Share request pop up at the bottom of your screen. If your phone was locked when you sent the image from your computer, swipe down to open the Notification panel on your Android, then tap the "File Share" notification to accept the share. View the photo on your phone or tablet by tapping Open . [8] X Research source

steps.title: Connect your iPhone to your Mac with a USB cable.
steps.content: Connect your iPhone to your Mac with a USB cable. iPhones after 15 have a USB-C connector that you can easily connect to your Mac. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Select your iPhone in Finder.
steps.content: Select your iPhone in Finder. It will be listed on the left side under "Locations."

steps.title: Click the Photos tab.
steps.content: Click the Photos tab. It's under your phone name and information.

steps.title: Select the checkbox next to "Sync photos to…" and make a selection.
steps.content: Select the checkbox next to "Sync photos to…" and make a selection. Use the drop-down menu to select your Photos app or a specific folder.

steps.title: Choose "Sync" and "Options."
steps.content: Choose "Sync" and "Options." Opt to sync all the photos available or specific files, or if you want to sync just your "Favorites" and whether to include videos.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . It's in the lower right corner and will immediately apply your settings. Depending on your choices above, you will find any synced or shared images or videos in your mobile Photos app. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Connect your iPhone to your computer.
steps.content: Connect your iPhone to your computer. Use the iPhone's charging cable to connect it to one of your computer's USB ports. [11] X Research source If you're on a Mac that doesn't have a USB port, you will need to purchase a USB-C to USB-3.0 adapter.

steps.title: Open iTunes.
steps.content: Open iTunes. If iTunes doesn't open automatically, double-click the iTunes program icon to open it. iTunes resembles a multicolored musical note on a white background.

steps.title: Click the iPhone icon.
steps.content: Click the iPhone icon. This iPhone-shaped icon is at the top of the iTunes window. Doing so opens the iPhone's page.

steps.title: Click Photos.
steps.content: Click Photos . This tab is in the left-hand sidebar below the "Settings" heading.

steps.title: Check the "Sync Photos" box.
steps.content: Check the "Sync Photos" box. It's at the top of the Sync Photos page. Doing so will allow you to add photos from your computer to your iPhone. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Click the "Copy photos from:" drop-down box.
steps.content: Click the "Copy photos from:" drop-down box. You'll find this option near the top of the Sync Photos page. Clicking it prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Choose folder….
steps.content: Click Choose folder… . It's at the top of the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select a folder.
steps.content: Select a folder. Click the folder from which you want to upload photos, then click Select Folder . [13] X Research source

steps.title: Select subfolders if necessary.
steps.content: Select subfolders if necessary. If the picture folder you selected has one or more folders in it that you don't want photos from, check the "Selected folders" radio button and then check each folder you want to use to upload photos. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Determine whether or not you want to include videos.
steps.content: Determine whether or not you want to include videos. Check the "Include videos" box in the middle of the page to upload videos in your selected folder, or leave the box unchecked to upload only pictures.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . Your selected photos will begin uploading to your iPhone. Once the photos finish uploading, they will appear on your iPhone.

steps.title: Connect your phone to your computer.
steps.content: Connect your phone to your computer. Attach one end of the charger cable to your Android and the other to your computer's USB port. This method will only work with an Android phone since iPhones require iTunes to transfer photos over a USB cable. Tap Media device (MTP) on your Android's screen if prompted.

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . Click the folder-shaped icon in the lower-left side of the Start window.

steps.title: Click your pictures folder.
steps.content: Click your pictures folder. This will normally be the Pictures folder in the left-hand sidebar, but if you're transferring images from a different location, click that folder in the sidebar instead.

steps.title: Select pictures to move.
steps.content: Select pictures to move. Click and drag your mouse across a group of pictures you want to select, or hold down Ctrl and click each picture you want to select individually. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Click Home.
steps.content: Click Home . This tab is in the upper-left corner of the window. A toolbar will appear below the Home tab area.

steps.title: Click Copy to.
steps.content: Click Copy to . It's a folder-shaped icon in the "Organize" section of the toolbar. Doing so prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Choose location….
steps.content: Click Choose location… . This option is at the bottom of the drop-down menu. A pop-up window will appear.

steps.title: Click your Android's name.
steps.content: Click your Android's name. You'll find it in the middle of the window, though you may have to scroll down first.

steps.title: Click the DCIM folder.
steps.content: Click the DCIM folder. It's below the Android's name. Doing so expands the DCIM folder to show its contents.

steps.title: Click the Camera folder.
steps.content: Click the Camera folder. This is below the DCIM folder. Click it to select the Camera folder as the copied images' destination.

steps.title: Click Copy.
steps.content: Click Copy . It's a button in the bottom-right corner of the pop-up window. Doing so will begin transferring the selected photos to your Android's internal storage; once there, they will be viewable from your Android's Photos app.

steps.title: Connect your Android to your Mac.
steps.content: Connect your Android to your Mac. Use the Android's charging cable to connect your Android to one of your computer's USB ports. [16] X Research source If your Mac doesn't have a USB port, you will need to purchase a USB-C to USB-3.0 adapter. If your Android prompts you to select a connection type, tap Media device (MTP) on its screen before continuing.

steps.title: Download and install Android File Transfer.
steps.content: Download and install Android File Transfer. To do so: [17] X Research source Go to http://www.android.com/filetransfer/ Click DOWNLOAD NOW Install Android File Transfer

steps.title: Open the Finder.
steps.content: Open the Finder. This blue-faced icon is in your Mac's Dock.

steps.title: Select your pictures' location.
steps.content: Select your pictures' location. Click the pictures' folder in the left-hand column of folders. This will open the folder in the Finder window.

steps.title: Select pictures to transfer.
steps.content: Select pictures to transfer. Click and drag your mouse across a group of pictures you want to select, or hold down ⌘ Command and click each picture you want to select individually.

steps.title: Copy the pictures.
steps.content: Copy the pictures. Click the Edit menu item, then click Copy in the resulting drop-down menu.

steps.title: Open Android File Transfer.
steps.content: Open Android File Transfer. If Android File Transfer doesn't automatically open, click the Launchpad spaceship icon, then click the Android File Transfer icon, which resembles a green Android mascot. You can also click Spotlight in the top-right corner of the screen, type in android file transfer , and then click the Android File Transfer icon.

steps.title: Double-click the Internal storage or SD card folder.
steps.content: Double-click the Internal storage or SD card folder. This step will vary depending on where you want to store your photos.

steps.title: Double-click the DCIM folder.
steps.content: Double-click the DCIM folder. This will open to another folder.

steps.title: Double-click the Camera folder.
steps.content: Double-click the Camera folder. It's where your Android's photos are stored.

steps.title: Paste the pictures into this folder.
steps.content: Paste the pictures into this folder. Click anywhere in the folder, then click Edit and click Paste Items in the drop-down menu. Your copied photos will begin being transferred to your Android. Once they finish doing so, you'll be able to view them in your Android's Photos app.
